> [mg0](#comment_1_1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa): Nice project, I'd like to know if you have some resources as to become aware of how all these security technologies work and how to use them (LUKS, TPM, etc...). I think this is important because otherwise what you work for looks like a lot of highly nerdy stuff that normal user won't ever get to use properly. Another thing is the addition of more cert signers for this blog, I'm posting this on my zeroid nick but I'd like to use my kaffieid one for a change, others may find it useful too.
> About the forum, it sounds like a good idea since it would be easier to reach old posts and allow for interaction and community, I don't know of any zite that looks forum-like enough; the closest call is ZeroTalk, you could clone it and tweak it for Insurgo needs.
> Keep zeroing~

Thanks for reaching out!
The high level stuff will be present on the official website soon enough. I was intending to reach more technical people here. But you should watch this talk and read this blog post by Heads project starter, Trammel Hudson: https://trmm.net/Heads_33c3. It covers it all, really.

But in short:

LUKS is just the disk encryption container used under Linux deployment. The reason this is a breakthrough is because normally, OEM cannot preinstall a Linux Operating System in such container without themselves having a copy of the LUKS Disk Recovery Key, which at time, they could hand to authorities, compromising users privacy. With Heads replacing the firmware (BIOS), which is coreboot with a linux payload, Heads permits to deploy necessary tools (cryptsetup-reencrypt) to reencrypt the container, which eencrypts the data in place, while permitting the user to change the LUKS Disk Recovery Key passphrase.

The TPM, or Trusted Platform Module, is a external root of trust that permits to measure things, XOR them one on top of another, and make sure the end result is the same. As a consequence for Heads, it permits to measure boot modules (romstage, and so on) to make sure they have not been modified, and some weapons of the Vault 7. Such modifications would modify the measurements and Heads would warn the user for possibile compromise. That is why we talk of tamper-evidence and not tamper-proofing here. The system could still be compromised, but the user would know it before booting it.

The Librem Key/Nitrokey serves as a external validating device, flashing green when those integrity measures from the TPM are valid.

As a result of this, QubesOs can now be preinstalled. The measurements of /boot and firmware are sealed in the Librem Key/Nitrokey and verifiable by the user at each boot. The reownership process i'm nearly done developping will take the user by the end in reowning those components, making the hardware his own and only upon reception. Note also that the ME module is neutered. The X230 laptop is really the best we currently have, privacy wise, for QubesOS.

> [mg0](#comment_2_1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa): I thought meltdown and spectre are based on out-of-order speculative branching, afaik that's not just related to SMT enabled processors, like, it should go back haunting really old processors and different architectures as well.

Yep, you're right, not everything is mitigated by switch hyperthreading off. 

Preventive exectution and side channels attacks are really complex problem to dissect and underlying vulnerabilities got mixed up in people's mind. Some fixes require microcode updates, some can be dodged through HVM/PVH virtualization (full virtualization), but again side channel attacks can be mitigated by deactivating HyperThreading like in ZombieLoad, while applying microcode/kernel updates that are available attempt to fix while retaining hyperthreading. 

But most importantly, the solution lies into making sure secrets that what you do not want to leak cannot leak; meaning: [not having them available at all times](https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-app-shutdown-idle).

This is why QubesOS is so interesting; you can limit exposition. Of yourself, your collaborators/clients data only for what is currently needed to be done, in specific compartments, thus empowering yourself to do proper preventive choices into creating the proper environments that work for you AND to protect efficiently your collaborators data. Monolithic operating systems,  containers sharing host memory and kernel and application sandboxing have serious limitations that HVM/PVH resolves. Nothing will ever be perfect, but closing our eyes on current architecture limitations is not an option.

Security will never be a product. It's a process. And user's awareness in there is key, which depends of its  [threat model](https://sec.eff.org/materials/threat-modeling-activity-handout-for-learners) deep awareness and the available energy to answer the fourth and most important question, which is, basically : what are you willing to deploy (energy wise) into putting proper mechanisms in place to protect you from such threats.


QSBs are available [here](https://www.qubes-os.org/security/bulletins/)
[Meltdown/Spectre related bulletin](https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-secpack/blob/master/QSBs/qsb-037-2018.txt)
Exerpt:
"Fully virtualized VMs offer significant protection against Meltdown"
"Virtualization makes at least one variant of Spectre seem difficult"
"Only running VMs are vulnerable"

[ZombieLoad related bulletin](https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-secpack/blob/master/QSBs/qsb-049-2019.txt)
Exerpt:
"Vulnerable data is that on the same physical core as the attacker. This includes, when hyper-threading is enabled, adjacent threads."

> [mg0](#comment_3_1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa): If the windows 7 VM is meant for being stateful, like, changes and files will stay across VM reboots, then you could use a sysprep'ed image, it removes unique stuff from a windows installation but that stuff should be recreated once the image is booted again. I've used it once to deploy that OS to about 20 machines or so quickly. It will uninstall already installed drivers in the machine you install (the machine in which you sysprep the image) so you could move the installation to another machine, may it be swapping hdds or cloning them altogether.
> Now, I can't help with the legal aspects, I'm pretty used to warez (hehe) and KMS makes activating everything really a breeze.

In QubesOS, the TemplateVM is instanciated in read only by the "qube" that used it as a template, discarding changes that are done upon reboot. Installing a software in the VM itself would work within a VM boot, but the TemplateVM wouldn't be touched at all and be dismissed upon reboot.

Activating a copy or installing software, updates, or syspreping the image would require to be done in the TemplateVM itself for the state to be kept in across reboots.

Now, my real question is, for privacy needs:  Does the image NEEDS to be sysprep'ed before being cloned to  individual physical machines TO NOT SHARE some unique identification, bound to Windows Installation ID?

Since we are talking about a VM, the "hardware" linked to the installation will always be the same across physical deployments, so the drivers being deployed for QubesOS VM<->Xen hypervisor are required to properly support network and disk operations (qvm-copy, XEN drivers, etc). So no need to make that installation generalized.

If for some reason, you forgot your LUKS Disk Recovery Key, the only solution is to reinstall QubesOS.

If that happens inside of the Re-Ownership process, you have to first turn off OEM Re-Ownership. Else skip to the next section.


DEACTIVATE RE-OWNERSHIP WIZARD IN HEADS

To do so, go directly into a recovery shell. To do so, hit frenetically the 'r' key after hitting the power button, prior to Heads booting up. Hit 'r' until you reach the recovery shell.

Then:
mount /boot
mount -o remount,rw /boot
rm /boot/oem
mount -o remount,ro /boot
 
The changes have be synced to your boot disk. Reboot



REINSTALL/INSTALL QUBESOS

WINDOWS IS PREINSTALLED ON THE MACHINE
When buying refurbished hardware, this normally comes with Windows preinstalled. Heads requires a Linux partition in /dev/sda1. If you are prompted to select an alternate boot drive, just select the option to go into recovery shell.

Into recovery shell, format the first partition of your hard drive into Linux partition:
mke2fs /dev/sda1
reboot

INSTALL QUBESOS:
Under Heads, select Settings ->> Boot Options -> Boot from SDCARD or Boot from USB

SEAL EVERYTHING BACK
On reboot, you are in a unknow state. No /boot files are signed, there is no Disk Unlock Key password set. The TPM counter file in /boot is no longer present.

Reseal TPM/HOTP:
Go in Settings -> TPM/TOTP/HOTP OPTIONS-> Reset the TPM
Choose a new TPM passphrase. It is suggested for it to match your GPG Admin PIN
You'll be asked to enter it twice, then once again to seal measurements.
Scan your new TPMTOTP Qr Code.
reboot

Sign boot configurations:
Settings -> Update checksums and sign all files in /boot
Type your GPG User PIN when requested.
reboot

DEFINE A NEW DEFAULT BOOT OPTION & DISK UNLOCK KEY
Settings-> Boot Options -> Show OS Boot menu (Select first option)
Select all default choices presented.
Enter Disk Recovery Key (Disk encryption passphrase selected)
Choose a Disk Unlock Passphrase (doesn't need to be crazy. 3 EFF diceware passphrase is more then enough.)
reboot

Voila!

Documenting as I go:
- "ocs-live-feed-img"
      script to which we pass arguments (code here:https://gitlab.com/stevenshiau/clonezilla/-/raw/master/sbin/ocs-live-feed-img) 

- "-cbm netboot " 
      " -cbm, --client-boot-mode MODE     Assign the client boot mode: netboot, local-boot-media, or both"
- "-dm start-new-dhcpd" 
      " -dm, --dhcpd-mode  MODE  Assign the dhcp service mode: use-existing-dhcpd, start-new-dhcpd, auto-detect, no-dhcpd" 
- "-lscm massive-deployment" 
      " -lscm, --lite-srv-client-mode MODE  Assign lite server client mode: massive-deployment or interactive-client"
- "-mdst from-device" 
      " -mdst, --massive-deploy-source-type MODE  Assign massive deployment source type: from-image or from-device" 
- "-bdt disk-2-mdisks" 
      " -bdt, --bt-dev-type MODE Assign BT device type: disk-2-mdisks or part-2-mparts" 
- "-bsdf sfsck" 
      " -bsdf, --bt-src-dev-fsck  TYPE   Assign the type for fsck the source device: sfsck, fsck, fsck-y. Do not put \"-\" before the TYPE. It will confuse $ocs. Use it like: \"-bsdf fsck-y\""
     " sfsck, --skip-fsck-src-part  Skip running fsck on the source file system before saving it."
- "-g auto" 
      " -g|--grub-install auto"
- "-e1 auto"
      " -e1, --change-geometry NTFS-BOOT-PARTITION Force to change the CHS (cylinders, heads, sectors) value of NTFS boot partition after image is restored. NTFS-BOOT-PARTITION can be one of \"/dev/sda1\", \"/dev/sda2\"... or \"auto\" (\"auto\" will let clonezilla detect the NTFS boot partition automatically)"  
- "-e2" 
      " -e2, --load-geometry-from-edd  Force to use the CHS (cylinders, heads, sectors) from EDD (Enhanced Disk Device) when creating partition table by sfdisk"
- "-r" 
       " -r, --resize-partition   Resize the file system size to fit the partition size in the destination disk. It is normally used when when a small partition image is restored to a larger partition."
- "-x" 
      " -x|--full-duplex"
- "-j2" 
      " -j, --create-part-by-sfdisk Use sfdisk to create partition table instead of using dd to dump the partition table from saved image (This is default)"
      " -j0, --create-part-by-dd  Use dd to dump the partition table from saved image instead of sfdisk. ///Note/// This does NOT work when logical drives exist."
      " -j1, --dump-mbr-in-the-end  Use dd to dump the MBR (total 512 bytes, i.e. 446 bytes (executable code area) + 64 bytes (table of primary partitions) + 2 bytes (MBR signature; # 0xAA55) = 512 bytes) after disk image was restored. This is an insurance for some hard drive has different numbers of cylinder, head and sector between image was saved and restored."
      " -j2, --clone-hidden-data  Use dd to clone the image of the data between MBR (1st sector, i.e. 512 bytes) and 1st partition, which might be useful for some recovery tool."
      " -e2, --load-geometry-from-edd  Force to use the CHS (cylinders, heads, sectors) from EDD (Enhanced Disk Device) when creating partition table by sfdisk"

- "-p true" 
      " -p|--postaction" 
- " -md bittorrent"  
      "-md|--massive-deploy-mode" 
- --clients-to-wait 5 
- start sda sda

This without changes: 

    ocs-live-feed-img -cbm netboot -dm start-new-dhcpd -lscm massive-deployment -mdst from-device -bdt disk-2-mdisks -bsdf sfsck -g auto -e1 auto -e2 -r -x -j2 -p true -md bittorrent --clients-to-wait 5 start sda sda

Becomes for sake of clarity:

    ocs-live-feed-img --client-boot-mode netboot --dhcpd-mode start-new-dhcpd --lite-srv-client-mode massive-deployment --massive-deploy-source-type from-device --bt-dev-type disk-2-mdisks --bt-src-dev-fsck sfsck --grub-install auto --change-geometry auto --load-geometry-from-edd --resize-partition --full-duplex --clone-hidden-data --postaction true --massive-deploy-mode bittorrent --clients-to-wait 5 start sda sda 

Where the thought culprits are linked to cfdisk options (-j and -e options) which will be replaced with dd.

A test run with the following will follow:
